TopicTitle: Do you know, how to stop crashes from happening?

Articles.Content: Most of you, veteran players tried out some mods. some of you have loads of mods and as you know installing too many mods make your game crash almost every fricking time you change secenery (from VAB to launchpad, or from space to tracking station etc.). Do you know any good way to reduce their freqency? It's a little pain to play with 35 different mods.

You need a mod called Active Texture Management, it will make KSP take slightly longer to start up buy can reduce memory usage by 1-2GB. Th reason it crashes is because KSP is hitting the 3.3/3.4GB memory allowance that 32-bit program's have, which will cause the crash, so ATM will help with this, see link here!

If you still have problems after installing that mod, post again. If so, do you run the game on Steam?

Damn... You might some success forcing the game to use OpenGL (guide here), some users (including me) found it can reduce memory usage considerably, but some suffer from FPS drops... Try it and see!

If you are running the 32 bit version you can also force openGL which will save you about 1GB of ram. to do this create a shortcut and then open the properties window and in the target line add -force-opengl to the end of it. Also, if you have lots of parts mods that add fuel tanks you can delete parts from mods that are redundant. (Like I have PParts and PFairings so I delete anything that has a fuel tank or a fairing)

Currently running 90+ mods at just over 2GB of memory usage.

Here's some advice:

1. Force KSP to use OpenGL. As the other posters said, it'll save you about 1GB of ram. If you're using Steam right click, go to Properties and click (on the first tab) Set Launch Options, you can put "-force-opengl" without the quotes in there.

2. If you're using Windows or Linux, try using the x64 build of the game. It's a separate executable in the KSP root folder, and can be launched via the Launcher executable.

4GB of RAM is nowhere near enough for KSP. Since your computer reserves 1GB for OS functions, you're left with only 3GB for KSP, which is a recipe for disaster as you'll quickly be hitting the RAM limit. With that aside, what's your CPU? KSP is more CPU-intensive than GPU-intensive due to the requirement for lots of physics-based calculations and the fact that the physics engine can only use 1 core, so you'll need a powerful CPU to run big ships well.
